description: From Middle English breden, from Old English brēdan, from Proto-Germanic *brōdijaną (“to brood”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰreh₁- (“warm”). Cognate with Scots brede, breid, Saterland Frisian briede, West Frisian briede, Dutch broeden, German Low German bröden, German brüten.

entries.meaning: All animals or plants of the same species or subspecies.
A race or lineage; offspring or issue.
(informal) A group of people with shared characteristics.
examples: People who were taught classical Greek and Latin at school are a dying breed.

verbs.description: breed (third-person singular simple present breeds, present participle breeding, simple past and past participle bred)

entries.meaning: To produce offspring sexually; to bear young.
(transitive) To give birth to; to be the native place of.
examples: a pond breeds fish; a northern country breeds stout men

entries.meaning: To keep animals and have them reproduce in a way that improves the next generation’s qualities.
To arrange the mating of specific animals.
examples: She wanted to breed her cow to the neighbor's registered bull.

entries.meaning: To propagate or grow plants trying to give them certain qualities.
examples: He tries to breed blue roses.

entries.meaning: To take care of in infancy and through childhood; to bring up.
examples: born and bred on the verge of the wilderness
disaster breeds famine;  familiarity breeds contempt

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To be formed in the parent or dam; to be generated, or to grow, like young before birth.
(sometimes as breed up) To educate; to instruct; to bring up
examples: His farm may not  […]  remove his children too far from him, or the trade he breeds them up in.

entries.meaning: To produce or obtain by any natural process.
(intransitive) To have birth; to be produced, developed or multiplied.
(transitive) To ejaculate inside; to attempt to impregnate.
examples: “God, I love your ass,” he says, his voice almost a growl. “I'm gonna breed this ass tonight.”
